page.title: 10Farms in general
page.content: Most are dairy farms with a cottage garden adjoining the farmhouse. Sizes vary from 80-150 acres (average 100). There is no large landowner, the Pole family sold out in the 1920s. At Platt Farm one of the sons has developed his own piggery, but this is an exception A few sheep are kept, but usually as a sideline. Poultry is kept on a small scale, especially turkeys, a constant watch is kept for foxes.To feed the cattle many fields are kept in grass (for silage), maize, rape or mangels. As farms have changed hands farmers have tended to buy or rent fields not adjacent to their own land and this often causes chaos in the narrow lanes as produce is taken to the home farm. A recent innovation is bulb growing. A Colyton businessman has rented fields for spring bulb growing, adding colour and increasing tourism.
